definition: fight a battle of words/cross verbal swords
variant of 唇[chun2]
lip
gun/firearm/rifle/spear/thing with shape or function similar to a gun/CL:支[zhi1],把[ba3],桿|杆[gan3],條|条[tiao2],枝[zhi1]/to substitute for another person in a test/to knock/classifier for rifle shots
surname Qiang
variant of 槍|枪[qiang1]/rifle/spear
tongue
double-edged sword/CL:口[kou3],把[ba3]/classifier for blows of a sword
variant of 劍|剑[jian4]

sentences.english: In the next free debate, the two sides are more thrust, I block you, and neck.
sentences.chinese: 里，双方更是唇枪舌剑，你来我挡，难解难分。

definition: war of words
verbal sparring/duel of words
debate/argument/to argue over/CL:場|场[chang3],次[ci4]
to oppose each other with equal harshness (idiom); tit for tat/measure for measure
lit. with swords drawn and bows bent (idiom); fig. a state of mutual hostility/at daggers drawn
sharply opposed to each other, with neither prepared to give an inch (idiom)
each sticks to his own view (idiom); a dialogue of the deaf
to fight openly and maneuver covertly (idiom)
neither giving way to the other
faulty argument and poor rhetoric (idiom); unable to put forward any convincing arguments/without a leg to stand on
dispute/spat/shouting match
lit. to quote the classics/to quote chapter and verse (idiom)
each sticks to his own opinion (idiom); chacun son gout
war of words
flushed with anger (or excitement)
to hurl abuse/to trade insults/slanging match
